shortText: Designs team topology aligned to value streams and cognitive load
fullExample: Reorganizes from layer-based to stream-aligned teams, mapping ownership to customer value flows with clear boundaries.
levelNotes: Directors design topology; EMs advocate for changes within their team
why: Teams organized by tech layer create handoff bottlenecks and can't own outcomes end-to-end
how: Map value streams, assign ownership boundaries, minimize cross-team handoffs, assess cognitive load per team
expectedResult: Teams ship independently; clear accountability; no 'I thought the other team owned that'

calibrationSignals.signalText: The foundational org design pattern. Directors must articulate team topology rationale: 'Reorganized from layer-based to stream-aligned teams, reducing cross-team handoffs by X%'
Key signal in re-org proposals: 'Team owns too much — proposed split based on cognitive load analysis'

shortText: Applies inverse Conway maneuver to align org structure with target architecture
fullExample: Restructures teams to match desired microservices architecture, enabling independent deployment per team.
levelNotes: Directors execute; EMs provide input on team-level implications
why: Architecture mirrors org structure whether planned or not — fighting Conway's Law always loses
how: Map current arch to team structure, find misalignments, restructure teams to match desired architecture
expectedResult: Architecture and org structure reinforce each other; service boundaries align with team boundaries

calibrationSignals.signalText: Director-level insight: 'Applied inverse Conway — re-orged teams to align with target microservices architecture, enabling independent deployment'

shortText: Executes re-orgs with structured communication and zero regrettable attrition
fullExample: Runs re-org of 30 engineers across 4 teams: managers told first, ICs within 24hrs, phased transition over 3 weeks, full productivity restored by week 4.
levelNotes: Directors initiate and own; EMs execute team-level transitions
why: Poorly run re-orgs destroy trust and productivity for months — people leave because of how it was handled
how: Communication plan (managers→ICs→broader org within 24hrs), phased transition, ownership transfer docs
expectedResult: Teams productive within 2-4 weeks; minimal attrition from re-org; people feel respected

calibrationSignals.signalText: 'Executed re-org of [X] engineers across [Y] teams with zero regrettable attrition and full productivity restored within 3 weeks'
Observed during re-org: communicated rationale in team all-hands with empathy and clarity, answered hard questions directly, followed up individually with affected engineers within 24 hours.

shortText: Recognizes re-org signals and acts before problems become crises
fullExample: Identifies growing coordination overhead and unclear ownership across two teams, proposes and executes split before productivity degrades.
levelNotes: Directors initiate; EMs surface signals from their team
why: Teams accumulate scope creep and unclear ownership invisibly over time
how: Monitor coordination overhead, ownership confusion, team size >10, >3 active contexts per team
expectedResult: Proactive structural changes; re-orgs feel intentional, not reactive

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors initiate re-orgs; EMs execute them. Both need to read the signals early

shortText: Maintains single-threaded ownership registry with no ambiguity
fullExample: Builds and maintains service→team→on-call→contact registry; resolves disputes by escalation, not by sharing ownership.
levelNotes: EMs maintain for their team; Directors enforce across org
why: Shared ownership = no ownership; diffusion of responsibility means nothing gets done well
how: Build ownership registry, resolve disputes formally, transfer ownership explicitly not by attrition
expectedResult: No ambiguity about who to page; clear accountability for outcomes

calibrationSignals.signalText: Amazon principle applied broadly — calibration rewards clear ownership stories: 'Established single-threaded ownership for [X], resolving [chronic issue]'

shortText: Sets coherent org-level goals aligned to business strategy with visible cross-team dependencies
fullExample: Creates cascading OKRs from business strategy to org objectives to team goals; maps cross-team dependencies; explicitly connects engineering work to business outcomes and revenue impact.
levelNotes: Directors own org-level; EMs align team goals upward
why: Team-level goals don't automatically add up to org outcomes; engineering goals framed in technical terms are invisible to business leadership and fail to earn investment.
how: Start from business strategy, decompose to org goals, then team OKRs. For each goal, articulate the business impact chain. Regular cross-team alignment reviews. Track org-level outcomes, not just team deliverables.
expectedResult: All teams rowing same direction; org-level goals met through coordinated execution

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors own the 'why' and 'what'; EMs own the 'how'. 'Set org OKRs, coordinated across [X] teams, achieved [Y]% of objectives'
The difference between 'shipped features' and 'drove business outcomes'. Directors who can't articulate this connection lose influence
calibrationSignals.sourceSubTopic: Aligning Team Goals to Business Strategy

shortText: Monitors org health dashboard and intervenes on early signals
fullExample: Tracks attrition, engagement scores, skip-level themes, and PTO usage monthly; catches burnout trend in one team before anyone resigns.
levelNotes: Directors own org-level dashboard; EMs provide team signals
why: Org problems are invisible until they explode — attrition spike, burnout wave, disengagement crisis
how: Dashboard: attrition rate, engagement scores, skip-level themes, 1:1 signals, PTO usage; review monthly
expectedResult: Early intervention on emerging problems; sustained org health; leadership trust

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors who lose people due to neglected org health lose credibility fast. 'Maintained org health score above [X] across [Y] teams for [Z] quarters'

shortText: Leads org through crisis while maintaining delivery on critical path
fullExample: During 20% RIF, owns communication, protects remaining team's morale, maintains delivery on top priorities, sees zero additional voluntary attrition for 6 months.
levelNotes: Directors lead org-level crises; EMs manage team-level impact
why: Layoffs and pivots shatter trust if handled badly; survivor guilt tanks productivity for months
how: Own crisis communication directly, be visible, acknowledge difficulty, protect morale, make quick decisions on what to pause
expectedResult: Org navigates crisis with minimal unnecessary damage; trust preserved; recovery is faster

calibrationSignals.signalText: Crisis leadership defines Director credibility. 'Led team through [X]% RIF, maintained team delivery, zero additional voluntary attrition in following 6 months'
Crisis leadership defines Director reputation. 'Led org through [crisis], maintained delivery on critical path, zero regrettable attrition during transition'

shortText: Delegates execution to EMs while operating at Director altitude
fullExample: Defines explicit ownership boundaries: Director owns strategy, cross-team, upward comms; EMs own team execution, 1:1s, sprint management. EMs escalate to Director only when criteria met.
levelNotes: Director-only capability
why: Directors who stay in EM-mode become bottlenecks; every decision routes through them, EMs never develop
how: Define what Director vs EM owns; intervention criteria; trust EMs with execution; track outcomes not activities
expectedResult: Director operates at right altitude; EMs develop independence; org scales beyond one person

calibrationSignals.signalText: Most common Director failure: not letting go of EM-level work. 'Delegated [X] to EMs, focused on [org-level initiative], resulting in [Y]'

shortText: Considers second-order effects and system-wide implications of decisions
fullExample: Before approving a team's velocity metric target, identifies that it would incentivize gaming and instead proposes a balanced scorecard approach.
levelNotes: EMs apply to team; Directors apply across org
why: Optimizing one team or metric can degrade the whole system — local maxima aren't global maxima
how: Map dependencies, identify feedback loops, check for unintended incentives, consult affected parties
expectedResult: Decisions improve the system, not just local metrics; fewer 'fixed A but broke B' situations

calibrationSignals.signalText: Director-level expectation: 'Considered org-wide implications, identified [unintended consequence], adjusted approach'

shortText: Runs structured planning process aligning eng investment to business priorities
fullExample: Leads H2 planning: gathers asks from PM/business/tech-debt/reliability, calculates real capacity, stack-ranks, gets stakeholder buy-in on final plan.
levelNotes: EMs own team-level; Directors own org-level planning
why: Without structured planning, eng investment drifts from business priorities each quarter
how: Intake asks, calculate real capacity (minus on-call/interviews/PTO/buffer), stack-rank, get buy-in
expectedResult: Clear plan stakeholders understand; team knows what they're building and why

calibrationSignals.signalText: EMs own team-level planning; Directors own org-level. 'Led H2 planning across [X] teams, aligned [Y] stakeholders, delivered [Z]% of committed roadmap'
Led quarterly planning that resulted in 30% reallocation of engineering investment toward highest-impact business priorities, documented with clear ROI analysis
Consistently produces planning artifacts that connect engineering work to business outcomes; stakeholders cite their planning process as a model for other teams

shortText: Declines requests by making trade-offs visible, not by saying no
fullExample: Responds to scope request with: 'Yes, if we deprioritize X — would you like to make that trade-off?' with data on impact of each option.
levelNotes: Both levels use this; Directors at org-level with VPs
why: Always saying yes creates debt mountains; always saying no burns relationships
how: Never say just 'no'; frame as resource constraint; offer alternatives with trade-offs
expectedResult: Focus on highest-impact work; relationships preserved; stakeholders own trade-offs jointly

calibrationSignals.signalText: The mark of a strong EM/Director: 'What you chose NOT to do, and why' — calibration values this over endless yeses
When they say no, it never feels like a rejection — they show you exactly what you'd be trading off and help you make the call yourself
Deflected 5 out-of-scope requests in Q3 by presenting trade-off analyses that stakeholders described as 'the clearest prioritization communication they'd seen'

shortText: Makes progress under ambiguity by matching decision rigor to reversibility
fullExample: Classifies a technology choice as reversible, ships in 2 days instead of 2 weeks; classifies a data model change as irreversible, invests 3 weeks in analysis.
levelNotes: Both levels; Directors model this for EMs
why: Ambiguity paralyzes teams that lack frameworks for deciding with incomplete information
how: Cost of delay? Cost of being wrong? Can we reverse? High reversibility → decide fast; low → invest in analysis
expectedResult: Forward progress even in uncertainty; willingness to course-correct when new info arrives

calibrationSignals.signalText: Leadership signal: 'Made [decision] with 70% confidence, built in reversibility, course-corrected at [point] — net outcome positive'
Distinguishes one-way door decisions from two-way door decisions and applies proportionate rigor; doesn't over-analyze reversible choices or under-analyze irreversible ones
In ambiguous situations where other teams stall, they find a way to make meaningful progress by scoping down the decision and iterating

shortText: Challenges assumptions using first principles when situation demands fresh thinking
fullExample: Questions why team is building a custom auth system; first-principles analysis reveals the original requirement no longer exists, saving 3 months of work.
levelNotes: Directors apply more broadly; EMs apply within team scope
why: Cargo-culting and historical inertia lead to wasted investment on outdated assumptions
how: Identify the assumption, challenge whether it's still true, decompose the problem from scratch
expectedResult: Novel solutions; decisions based on current reality, not historical inertia

calibrationSignals.signalText: First principles thinking separates strategic leaders from operational ones. 'Challenged assumption that [X was necessary], saved [Y] by redesigning from first principles'
Challenged the team's assumption that a full rewrite was needed by applying first-principles analysis, resulting in a targeted migration that saved 3 months of engineering time
Regularly surfaces assumptions that others take as given; asks 'why do we believe this?' in a way that sharpens team thinking rather than undermining confidence

shortText: Authors and maintains multi-quarter technical vision with clear migration path
fullExample: Co-authors tech strategy doc with Staff engineers: current state → target state → migration path → success metrics. Reviews quarterly against delivery reality.
levelNotes: EMs co-author for their area; Directors set vision across org
why: Teams lack coherent direction without it; engineers make conflicting architectural decisions
how: Collaborate with TL/Staff+ to author; structure as current→target→migration→metrics; review quarterly
expectedResult: Team ships coherently toward goals; new engineers read one doc and understand system direction

calibrationSignals.signalText: Promo packet: 'Authored and drove technical vision for [area], adopted by [X] teams, enabling [measurable outcome]'

shortText: Runs architecture reviews covering service boundaries, modularity, and design quality
fullExample: Creates RFC template with required sections, sets review cadence, evaluates service boundary decisions against team topology and cognitive load, maintains searchable decision log. Reviews prevent both monolith coupling and over-decomposition.
levelNotes: EMs run for team; Directors institutionalize across org
why: Inconsistent design quality; service boundaries don't match team boundaries (violating Conway's Law); monolith coupling slows all teams while over-decomposition adds coordination overhead.
how: RFC template with alternatives/rollback/SLO impact. Review evaluates: does this service boundary align with team ownership? Does modularity reduce or increase coordination? Decision log for posterity. Use RACI to clarify review roles.
expectedResult: Fewer production surprises; faster onboarding; durable decision records

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors: 'Institutionalized design review process across org — reduced production incidents from design gaps by X%'
Conway's Law in practice: 'Realigned service boundaries to team topology, reduced cross-team deploy coordination by X%'

Observed in design reviews: asks probing questions about coupling and blast radius, pushes back on designs that create cross-team dependencies, references team topology constraints in architectural decisions.

shortText: Makes build-vs-buy decisions using repeatable framework with TCO analysis
fullExample: Evaluates vendor solution using 3-year TCO including maintenance, lock-in risk, and team capability fit; saves 6 eng-months by buying instead of building.
levelNotes: EMs own team-level; Directors broker org-level platform decisions
why: Teams default to building when buying is faster, or buy solutions they outgrow in 6 months
how: Evaluate: differentiation value, 3yr TCO, team capability fit, vendor lock-in, time-to-value
expectedResult: Custom where it differentiates, commodity where it doesn't; fewer regretted decisions

calibrationSignals.signalText: Demonstrates strategic thinking: 'Saved [X] eng-months by buying [tool] instead of building, redirected capacity to [high-value project]'

shortText: Manages tech debt systematically with explicit capacity allocation
fullExample: Maintains debt inventory classified by severity, allocates 15-20% sprint capacity, tracks impact of paydown on delivery metrics.
levelNotes: EMs own team debt; Directors ensure allocation discipline across teams
why: Unchecked debt slows velocity quarter over quarter; over-investment in debt starves features
how: Debt inventory with severity classification, 15-20% sprint allocation, measure paydown impact
expectedResult: Sustained velocity without crippling debt; stakeholders see engineering as responsible stewards

calibrationSignals.signalText: Promo packet: 'Reduced incident rate X% and deployment time Y% through strategic tech debt paydown of [specific systems]'

shortText: Defines SLOs with error budgets that drive reliability trade-offs
fullExample: Partners with SRE to set SLOs per service, defines error budgets, uses budget consumption as signal to slow feature work and invest in reliability.
levelNotes: EMs own per-service SLOs; Directors own SLO culture across org
why: Without clear targets, every incident feels like a crisis and reliability investment is reactive
how: Set SLOs for latency/availability/error rates, define error budgets, dashboard with burn rate alerts
expectedResult: Objective reliability targets informing trade-offs; team knows when to invest in reliability

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors own SLO culture across their org; EMs own per-service. 'Established SLO framework, reduced Sev1s by X% through error budget discipline'

shortText: Plans and executes migrations incrementally without business disruption
fullExample: Uses strangler fig pattern to migrate system serving 10K QPS: parallel running with comparison testing, phased rollout with feature flags, zero customer-facing incidents.
levelNotes: EMs execute team-level; Directors own cross-org migration strategy
why: Big-bang migrations fail; team burns out on multi-quarter migrations without incremental value
how: Strangler fig pattern, feature flags, parallel running, phased rollout, track progress metrics
expectedResult: Successful migrations with minimal disruption; team doesn't burn out

calibrationSignals.signalText: High-visibility promo evidence: 'Led migration of [system] serving [X] QPS from [old] to [new] with zero customer-facing incidents'

shortText: Maintains observability standards and dependency maps enabling fast incident diagnosis
fullExample: Defines structured logging format, required metrics per service, end-to-end trace propagation, and dependency maps with fallback strategies; reduces mean time to diagnose from 4 hours to 20 minutes.
levelNotes: EMs own team instrumentation; Directors standardize across org
why: Without observability, debugging is guesswork and incidents take hours to diagnose
how: Define standards (structured logs, required metrics, trace propagation), instrument critical paths, map upstream/downstream dependencies with health checks and fallback patterns, set alerting thresholds.
expectedResult: Fast incident diagnosis (<15min to root cause); data-driven performance optimization

calibrationSignals.signalText: Cross-org impact awareness: 'Mapped [X] critical dependencies, implemented fallbacks, reduced cascading failures by Y%'
Table-stakes expectation — absence is a red flag. 'Instrumented [X] services, reduced mean time to diagnose from Y hours to Z minutes'

shortText: Establishes operating cadences with clear purposes and measurable outputs
fullExample: Creates quarterly planning, weekly ops review, and async status cadence — each with defined roles, inputs, and outputs. Eliminates 3 meetings with unclear purpose.
levelNotes: EMs own team cadence; Directors standardize across org
why: Without clear cadences, teams drift between meetings that produce nothing and chaos with no alignment
how: Define each meeting's purpose, inputs, outputs, cadence; eliminate purposeless meetings
expectedResult: Predictable rhythm; everyone knows what's expected; meetings are useful, not performative

calibrationSignals.signalText: EMs define team's communication operating system. The test: can a new hire figure out how information flows within their first week?

shortText: Tracks delivery commitments with measurable KPIs and >85% hit rate
fullExample: Creates commitment tracking with planned-vs-delivered ratio, velocity trend, and carryover rate; team consistently delivers 85%+ of committed work.
levelNotes: EMs own team delivery; Directors benchmark across teams
why: Without measurement, delivery is unpredictable and stakeholder trust erodes
how: Track commitment accuracy, velocity trend, carryover rate (<10%); use velocity for planning, never for evaluation
expectedResult: Predictability for stakeholders; sustainable pace; early warning when something is off

calibrationSignals.signalText: Execution credibility: 'Team delivers 85%+ of committed work consistently' — this earns trust and autonomy from leadership
'Team delivers 85%+ of committed work consistently' — execution credibility that earns autonomy

shortText: Invests in developer experience and tooling with measurable productivity gains
fullExample: Reduces CI pipeline from 45min to 8min, reclaiming 200 developer-hours/week; tracks build times, test duration, and local dev setup time.
levelNotes: EMs drive team-level DX; Directors justify org-level DX investment
why: Slow builds, flaky tests, and broken dev environments silently drain engineering capacity
how: Instrument pipeline stages, set targets, dedicate capacity for DX improvements, measure impact
expectedResult: Developers spend time coding not waiting; measurable productivity gains

calibrationSignals.signalText: Concrete impact: 'Reduced CI pipeline from 45min to 8min, reclaiming [X] developer-hours/week across team'
Observed in sprint reviews: team consistently delivers within 10% of committed scope, EM flags risks early in standup rather than at sprint end, retro action items are tracked to completion.

shortText: Eliminates toil through automation with tracked capacity reclamation
fullExample: Runs toil audit, identifies top 3 manual processes, automates them, reclaims equivalent of 1 FTE in capacity per quarter.
levelNotes: EMs drive team-level; Directors track org-level toil reduction
why: Toil accumulates invisibly and drains capacity from value-creating work
how: Run toil audit (1 week logging), calculate cost, prioritize by frequency × time × people affected
expectedResult: Engineering time redirected from maintenance to value creation; morale improves

calibrationSignals.signalText: Leverage-thinking: 'Automated [X], saving [Y] eng-hours/quarter, equivalent to [Z] FTE capacity reclaimed'

shortText: Implements risk-appropriate release process with automated rollback
fullExample: Deploys with canary (1%→10%→50%→100%), automated rollback triggers on error rate spike, feature flags decoupling deploy from release.
levelNotes: EMs own team release process; Directors standardize risk tiers across org
why: One-size-fits-all release process is either too slow for low-risk or too risky for high-risk changes
how: Feature flags, canary deployments, staged rollouts, automated rollback, risk-tiered process
expectedResult: Ship fast with confidence; quick rollback when things go wrong

calibrationSignals.signalText: EMs own release culture for their team; Directors standardize risk-appropriate release practices across org
EMs should articulate their team's testing philosophy: 'We test [this way] because [this reason], resulting in [this outcome]'

shortText: Maintains code review culture with <24hr SLA and knowledge distribution
fullExample: Sets review SLA target, implements reviewer rotation for knowledge spread, tracks review bottleneck trends.
levelNotes: EMs own team review culture directly
why: Slow reviews block flow; single-reviewer bottlenecks create bus factor risk
how: Review SLA (<24hr), reviewer rotation, review quality feedback in retros
expectedResult: Quality gate + knowledge sharing; no single reviewer bottleneck

calibrationSignals.signalText: Healthy review culture is a team health indicator. 'Implemented review SLA, reduced review bottleneck from 3 days to <8 hours'

shortText: Protects team focus with interrupt budget and scope change process
fullExample: Designates rotating interrupt handler per sprint, defines escalation criteria for true urgency, requires explicit trade-off for any mid-sprint scope addition.
levelNotes: EMs own directly; Directors set org-level expectations
why: Unmanaged interrupts fragment focus; scope creep erodes trust in commitments
how: Interrupt rotation, escalation criteria, scope change requires deprioritization trade-off
expectedResult: Teams can deep-focus; urgent issues still handled; scope changes are deliberate

calibrationSignals.signalText: Shows team management maturity: 'Protected team focus by [implementing interrupt rotation], delivered [project] on schedule despite [X] interrupt requests'

shortText: Runs retrospectives with >80% action item completion rate
fullExample: Bi-weekly retros with strict format, action items with owners, tracked completion rate, specific process improvements implemented each quarter.
levelNotes: EMs own team retros; Directors coach on retro effectiveness
why: Retros without follow-through teach teams that feedback doesn't matter
how: Bi-weekly retros, strict format (worked/didn't/actions), track completion, experiment with changes
expectedResult: Continuous improvement; team feels agency; problems get fixed not just discussed

calibrationSignals.signalText: Evidence of learning culture: 'Team retro action item completion rate >80%, resulting in [specific improvements]'

shortText: Maintains healthy Eng/PM/Design triad with joint roadmap ownership
fullExample: Runs weekly triad syncs with shared context: PM shares business data, Design shares user research, Eng shares technical constraints. Disagreements resolved through data, not hierarchy.
levelNotes: EMs own team-level triad; Directors broker org-level partnerships
why: Misaligned triad causes rework, delays, scope fights, and blame games
how: Regular triad syncs, shared context, joint roadmap ownership, structured disagreement resolution
expectedResult: Aligned decisions balancing user needs, business goals, and technical feasibility

calibrationSignals.signalText: 'Strong partner feedback from PM and Design' — explicit calibration dimension at most Big Tech companies

shortText: Navigates PM disagreements by framing trade-offs in business terms
fullExample: Responds to PM's deadline pressure by quantifying tech debt cost: 'This approach costs 200 eng-hours in maintenance over 3 quarters' and proposes three options with trade-offs.
levelNotes: Both levels; Directors model for EMs
why: EMs who just say no are ineffective; EMs who always say yes create debt mountains
how: Frame in business terms, propose alternatives (not just no), escalate with data if stuck
expectedResult: Decisions balance short-term needs with long-term health; PM trusts your judgment

calibrationSignals.signalText: EMs who just say 'no' to PM are ineffective. EMs who always say 'yes' create debt mountains. The skill is the nuance between them

shortText: Proactively shapes product strategy through technical insight
fullExample: Identifies a new API capability that enables a product surface PM hadn't considered; presents with user impact framing, leading to a roadmap pivot.
levelNotes: EMs contribute for team scope; Directors influence org-level product strategy
why: When engineering is treated as feature factory, technical possibilities don't inform product direction
how: Identify technical opportunities, present to PM with user impact framing, participate in product strategy
expectedResult: Product strategy informed by technical possibilities; engineering seen as creative partner

calibrationSignals.signalText: Director-level: 'Technical insight led to [product direction change], driving [Y] outcome that PM hadn't considered'
Observed in cross-functional syncs: PM and Design actively seek EM's input on scope trade-offs, EM raises technical constraints without blocking, disagreements resolved constructively in the room.

shortText: Resolves cross-team dependencies through partnership, not escalation
fullExample: Builds relationship with partner EM before needing anything; frames dependency request as mutual benefit; unblocks project without VP involvement.
levelNotes: EMs negotiate team-level; Directors broker org-level dependencies
why: Dependencies on teams with different priorities can stall your roadmap indefinitely
how: Build relationship early, understand partner's priorities, frame as mutual benefit, contribute back
expectedResult: Dependencies resolved through partnership; both teams benefit; relationship preserved

calibrationSignals.signalText: Influence skill: 'Negotiated priority alignment with [partner team], unblocking [project] without escalation'
'Strong TPM partnership enabled [X] cross-team initiative to deliver on time across [Y] teams'

shortText: Builds effective partnerships with platform, infra, and support functions
fullExample: Joins platform team's planning process, provides clear requirements with business justification, contributes bug fixes back; team's needs reflected in platform roadmap.
levelNotes: EMs partner at team level; Directors broker org-level platform investment
why: Platform teams serve many customers; your needs get deprioritized without active partnership
how: Attend their roadmap reviews, provide requirements with justification, contribute back, offer to be design partner
expectedResult: Your needs reflected in platform roadmaps; mutual investment creates better platform for everyone

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors broker org-level platform partnerships: 'Partnered with [platform team] on [capability], adopted by [X] teams'
Increasingly important partnership. 'Built DS collaboration model that increased experiment velocity from X to Y experiments/quarter'
'Built pre-approved design patterns for [privacy scenario], eliminating [X] weeks of launch-blocking legal review'

shortText: Manages up intentionally to build trust, autonomy, and sponsorship
fullExample: Understands manager's priorities; brings solutions not just problems; pre-wires before surprises; manager advocates for team in rooms they're not in.
levelNotes: Both levels; the #1 relationship for career trajectory
why: Manager relationship determines impact ceiling, autonomy level, and career trajectory
how: Understand their priorities, bring solutions, no surprises, pre-wire them, make them look good
expectedResult: Strong sponsorship; more autonomy; manager advocates in rooms you're not in

calibrationSignals.signalText: Navigating leadership transitions is a survival skill. 'Built trust with new [Director/VP] within 30 days, aligned roadmap to new priorities, maintained team stability'
Your manager is your primary sponsor in calibration and promo discussions. Invest in this relationship deliberately

shortText: Builds political capital through consistent delivery and helping others succeed
fullExample: Accumulates trust by: delivering consistently, sharing credit, unblocking peer teams, following through on every commitment. Trusted advisor for domain decisions.
levelNotes: Both levels; compounds over time and pays off enormously
why: Influence comes from accumulated trust and credibility, not from title
how: Deliver consistently, help others succeed, follow through on all commitments, share information proactively
expectedResult: Opinions carry weight; doors open; trusted advisor for cross-org decisions

calibrationSignals.signalText: Director-level: trust is the currency of cross-org execution. Built through consistent follow-through, not team-building exercises
The 90-day window determines your trajectory. 'Established credibility by [quick win], built stakeholder trust through [action]'
Compound interest of engineering leadership — builds slowly, pays off enormously. 'Trusted advisor to [peer/senior leaders] for [domain] decisions'

shortText: Pre-wires alignment across orgs before formal decision meetings
fullExample: Has 1:1 conversations with each stakeholder before group meeting; creates shared context document; proposes strawman for reaction. Drives convergence without VP forcing it.
levelNotes: Directors use extensively; EMs learn the pattern
why: Getting 4 teams to agree when you don't manage them is pure influence — cold meetings rarely converge
how: Pre-wire with 1:1s, create shared context doc, propose strawman, let others edit toward consensus
expectedResult: Org-level initiatives move forward without escalation; seen as someone who makes things happen

calibrationSignals.signalText: Director-level core competency: 'Drove alignment across [X] orgs on [Y] initiative without escalation'

shortText: Builds sponsor relationships with senior leaders for visibility and advocacy
fullExample: Delivers visible results, presents at VP reviews, volunteers for cross-org initiatives; VP sponsors them for scope expansion.
levelNotes: Directors actively cultivate; EMs begin building
why: Mentors give advice; sponsors give opportunities. Without sponsors, you're invisible above skip-level
how: Deliver visible results, seek exposure, volunteer for initiatives they care about, build genuine relationship
expectedResult: Opportunities come to you; work gets visibility; advocates in promotion and scope discussions

calibrationSignals.signalText: Sponsors are essential for promotion above Director level. 'Sponsored by [VP] for [opportunity/promotion]'

shortText: Navigates scope ambiguity by demonstrating capability, not political maneuvering
fullExample: When scope between two orgs is ambiguous, demonstrates competence by delivering in the space; frames expansion in terms of customer benefit; builds coalition of supporters.
levelNotes: Director-level skill for scope expansion
why: Ambiguous ownership + growth = territory disputes that burn relationships if handled wrong
how: Demonstrate capability first, frame as customer/org benefit, build coalition, be transparent
expectedResult: Scope expands through earned trust; relationships preserved

calibrationSignals.signalText: Director skill: 'Expanded org scope to include [X] based on [demonstrated capability], increasing org impact by [Y]'

shortText: Runs structured 1:1s that build trust and drive career development
fullExample: Weekly 1:1s with shared doc; 60% their agenda / 20% yours / 20% career; follows through on every commitment. Skip-level feedback confirms quality.
levelNotes: EMs own directly; Directors coach EMs on 1:1 effectiveness
why: Without structured 1:1s, problems fester, careers stagnate, and trust erodes slowly 1:1s that become status updates are the most common failure mode.
how: Consistent cadence, shared running doc, balanced agenda, follow-through, separate career conversations quarterly
expectedResult: Trust built over time; early problem detection; career development progress; no perf review surprises

calibrationSignals.signalText: Foundation of people management. Skip-level feedback reveals 1:1 quality: 'My manager makes time for me and follows through'
Retention correlates with career development quality. 'All direct reports have active development plans reviewed quarterly'

shortText: Addresses underperformance early with clear expectations and genuine support
fullExample: Verifies expectations were clear, documents specific gaps with examples, sets improvement plan with milestones, holds weekly check-ins; person either improves or exits with dignity.
levelNotes: EMs execute directly; Directors coach EMs through difficult cases
why: Delayed feedback leaves people confused; the team suffers while the EM avoids the conversation
how: Verify expectations, document gaps with examples, set milestones, weekly check-ins, genuine coaching
expectedResult: Underperformers improve or exit; high performers feel valued; team standards maintained

calibrationSignals.signalText: THE hardest EM skill. Calibration committees notice avoidance — 'entire team rated Exceeds Expectations' is a credibility killer

Observed in skip-levels: direct reports describe clear expectations and regular feedback from EM. EM addresses performance issues directly rather than routing around struggling engineers or reassigning their work silently.

shortText: Identifies flight risk through behavioral signals and intervenes proactively
fullExample: Notices reduced engagement and vague answers about future plans from key engineer; conducts stay interview, surfaces growth concern, creates stretch assignment. Engineer stays.
levelNotes: EMs catch individual signals; Directors track patterns across teams
why: By the time someone gives notice, the decision was made weeks ago — early signals are the intervention window
how: Watch for: reduced engagement, declining quality, withdrawing from optional activities; conduct stay interviews
expectedResult: Early intervention on retention risks; save key people before they mentally check out

calibrationSignals.signalText: Directors track attrition patterns across teams; EMs catch individual signals. 'Zero regrettable attrition in [X] quarters through proactive retention'
